questions.prompt: What is the primary purpose of an Instruction Set Architecture (ISA)?
options: To specify the interface between software and hardware
To manage memory allocation in the operating system
To define the physical layout of transistors on a chip
To determine the clock speed of a processor
questions.explanation: An ISA defines the abstract interface between software and hardware, specifying instructions, registers, memory model, and data types that programs can use.

questions.prompt: In a 32-bit MIPS R-format instruction, how many bits are allocated for the opcode field?
questions.explanation: MIPS R-format instructions use 6 bits for the opcode field, which is used in conjunction with the funct field to specify the operation.

questions.prompt: Which addressing mode uses the instruction itself to contain the operand value?
questions.explanation: Immediate addressing embeds the operand value directly in the instruction, requiring no memory access to fetch the operand.

questions.prompt: What distinguishes a load-store architecture from a memory-memory architecture?
options: Only load and store instructions can access memory
questions.explanation: In a load-store architecture, arithmetic/logic operations only work with registers; memory access requires explicit load/store instructions.

questions.prompt: Which type of ISA design typically has fixed-length instructions?
questions.explanation: RISC architectures typically use fixed-length instructions for simpler decoding and pipelining, while CISC often uses variable-length instructions.

questions.prompt: In base+offset addressing, the effective address is calculated as:
questions.explanation: Base+offset (or displacement) addressing adds a constant offset to the contents of a base register to compute the effective address.

questions.prompt: What is the maximum immediate value that can be represented in a MIPS I-format instruction?
options: Both B and C depending on interpretation
questions.explanation: The 16-bit immediate can represent 0-65535 unsigned or -32768 to +32767 signed, depending on how the instruction interprets it.

questions.prompt: PC-relative addressing is most commonly used for:
questions.explanation: PC-relative addressing calculates the target address relative to the current PC, which is ideal for nearby branch targets.

questions.prompt: Which instruction format would MIPS use for the instruction "add $t0, $t1, $t2"?
questions.explanation: R-format is used for register-to-register operations like add, which specify three registers (rd, rs, rt).

questions.prompt: What is the purpose of the "funct" field in MIPS R-format instructions?
options: To extend the opcode for more operation types
questions.explanation: The funct field provides additional opcode bits for R-format instructions, allowing the same opcode to specify different operations.

title: CISC vs RISC and Modern ISAs

questions.prompt: Which characteristic is typical of CISC architectures?
questions.explanation: CISC architectures feature complex instructions that may take multiple cycles and can perform memory access with arithmetic operations.

questions.prompt: Modern x86 processors internally convert CISC instructions to:
questions.explanation: Modern x86 CPUs decode complex CISC instructions into simpler RISC-like micro-operations for efficient execution.

questions.prompt: ARM is classified as which type of architecture?
questions.explanation: ARM is RISC-inspired with load-store design and fixed-length instructions, though newer versions add some complex instructions.

questions.prompt: What advantage does RISC-V being open-source provide?
options: No licensing fees and customization freedom
questions.explanation: RISC-V is open-source with no licensing fees, allowing anyone to implement and customize it without paying royalties.

questions.prompt: Why do RISC architectures typically use more instructions to accomplish the same task as CISC?
options: RISC has simpler, more primitive instructions
questions.explanation: RISC uses simpler primitive instructions, so complex operations require multiple instructions, but each executes quickly.
